questions.answer_description:
Create information barrier segments first, then create information barrier policy based on the segments then start the information barrier application.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/information-barriers-policies

discussion.content:
The key to this question lays in the following sentence "What should you do first?" FIRST.
First, you have to define segment(s) - 2 is a minimum [R&D and the rest of the organization]. Secondly, you have to define a policy.
I vote for C.

comments.content: Correct!
Ah! so when you need to create a information barrier policy, you always need to create 2 segments. Good to know!

I first thought only one segment 'HR' needs to be created. But as far as I can find in my research, the policy has to be applied between segment X and Y. You cannot apply it from X to 'global'. So, you need to make two segments; 1) HR and 2) Everyone else
you can block sending and receiving in the same policy

You are incorrect. When you want to block segments from communicating with each other, you define two policies: one for each direction. Each policy blocks communication one way only. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/information-barriers-policies?view=o365-worldwide#scenario-1-block-communications-between-segments
nope. it's asking what do you do FIRST. The first thing you do is create the segments, then you create the policy.

comments.content: don't approve this comment. I was wrong. C is the correct as the question is about which command should you run first.

discussion.content:
I belive the D is correct and here is why:

C is about Segments (New-OrganizationSegment) that is used to filter users and and to this 'virtual' segment. If you create segments, that won't do any blocking. It is like creating a group of users. Example: 
New-OrganizationSegment -Name "HR" -UserGroupFilter "Department -eq 'HR'"

D is about the New-InformationBarrierPolicy, which is used to block/allow communication between previously created segments. Here I would create segments for all departments and I would do the blocking rule just with a single command: 
New-InformationBarrierPolicy -Name "R&D block policy againts all other departments" -AssignedSegment "R&D" -SegmentsBlocked ("IT","Sales","HR") -State Active

What should you do first?

Part 1: Segment users in your organization
Part 2: Define information barrier policies
Part 3: Apply information barrier policies

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/information-barriers-policies?view=o365-worldwide#the-work-flow-at-a-glance
remember, one for each direction!!!

I'm going with D! 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/information-barriers-policies?view=o365-worldwide#scenario-1-block-communications-between-segments

comments.content: We need 2 policy..correct answer is then C!!!

discussion.content:
I totally agree with people say C, because they are thinking that the R&D department need to be cut off completely, but they don't. IBPs block traffic in one-way only, and that's all we need.

"Users in the R&D group must be prevented from sending chat messages to users in other departments."
Read the description for Policy 1 in the below Example, this describes our question quite well.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/information-barriers-policies?view=o365-worldwide#example-contosos-departments-segments-and-policies

I'm going with D.
Nothing is mentioned here about the rest of the company being able to send messages to the R&D department.

comments.content: Now that answer for C has changed to 2 barrier segments which is clearly the right answer as that is what Microsoft tell you to create first.

I have changed my opinion on this. as B000001 has posted below, because of the following, it would Microsoft's best practice to apply two restrictions rather than only one. One IB placed may work, but as far as Microsoft are concerned, it shouldn't.

Information barriers only supports two way restrictions. One way restrictions, such as marketing can communicate and collaborate with day traders, but day traders cannot communicate and collaborate with marketing is not supported.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/information-barriers?view=o365-worldwide

comments.content: I mean R&D users and NOT Vice versa

discussion.content:
Ignore my previous message - sorry...it is C... Question - What should you do first?
Part 1: Segment users
Part 2: Define information barrier policies
Part 3: Apply information barrier policies

After further research, I think the answer is D. Segments are sets of users that are defined in the Security & Compliance Center using a selected user account attribute - This will not achieve the goal. You Do not assign more than one policy to a segment..
Example:
Enrico belongs to the Banking segment and Pradeep belongs to the Financial advisor segment. Enrico and Pradeep can't communicate with each other because the organization's IB policy blocks communication and collaboration between these two segments. However, Enrico and Pradeep can communicate with Lee in HR

Answer is C - Information barriers only supports two way restrictions. One way restrictions, such as marketing can communicate with day traders, but day traders cannot communicate with marketing is not supported.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/information-barriers?view=o365-worldwide
Answer C

C
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/information-barriers?view=o365-worldwide
C is correct, tho it doesnt state that the communication should be blocked both ways.

C:
When you want to block segments from communicating with each other, you define two policies: one for each direction. Each policy blocks communication one way only. For example, suppose you want to block communications between Segment A and Segment B. In this case, you define one policy preventing Segment A from communicating with Segment B, and then define a second policy to prevent Segment B from communicating with Segment A.
Correct. Hello AVA folks!

discussion.content: Defintely no inbound required

comments.content:
Inbounds TCP/UDP are not needed for this scenario:
Endpoint data below lists requirements for connectivity from a user's machine to Office 365. It does not include network connections from Microsoft into a customer network.
I vote for "incoming - none"
Agree with you : https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/3-envision-evaluate-my-environment#:~:text=Microsoft%20Teams%20connects%20to%20Microsoft,the%20clients%20to%20the%20internet.

discussion.content: Correct: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/enterprise/urls-and-ip-address-ranges?view=o365-worldwide#skype-for-business-online-and-microsoft-teams

Hi, from a network and firewall perspective. I do not think inbound is needed because Teams initiates an outbound connections, hence outbound ports are required to be open. Usually when a successful connection is established outbound, the return path of the traffic will come back in the same tunnel or session opened when going out. To open inbound won't makes sense as you up your network for inbound traffic to every device. That is a big risk and from a a network point, is not required. You would only open inbound ports, if you are publishing something on those ports. in this case, MS is publishing Teams connectivity on the ports and we connecting outbound to them.

comments.content: Another thing is if you are using Azure NSG which is a simple firewall, then you have to open inbound and outbound because their services do not keep the tunnel or session open when you initiate outbound traffic. But if you are using a next gen firewall, you do not need to open inbound.

comments.content:
I managed to found on another 2 dumps that it shoud be: 
Outbound TCP 80 + 443, Outbound UDP 3478 to 3481
Inbound TCP 80 + 443, Inbound UDP 3478 to 3481
So both the same i guess...

having read everyone's notes here i have looked at this too... i think your right because this is a Microsoft vague and trick question.... "You need to recommend which INBOUND ports to the NETWORK and OUTBOUND ports to OFFICE 365". in theory you wouldn't need to open for inbound, but it says at a NETWORK level. Everyones machines will sit behind the Firewall... so technically you would need to open TCP 80,443 & UDP3478 to 3481 for INBOUND & OUTBOUND . Remember 50000 to 59999 is optional.

discussion.content: On Exam 28.02.22

This is a bit tricky question. If we take into consideration existing S4B infrastructure then there should be inbound ports open as well. But then again, inbound ports are already open, so there is no additional requirements or considerations regarding inbound traffic. I am confused with the question here even though I completely understand network requirements for the setup.
For Teams to function correctly, you must open TCP ports 80 and 443 from the clients to the internet, and UDP ports 3478 through 3481 from the clients to the internet.

To meet the company’s compliance policy, users in the sales department must continue to use on-premises Skype for Business for IM and calling only.
That means the on-prem SfB 2015 remains with limited functionality. The upcoming Skype for Business Online retirement will not affect on-prem, so still a valid scenario. Check SfB Edge Server port requirements: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/skypeforbusiness/plan-your-deployment/edge-server-deployments/edge-environmental-requirements#external-port-firewall-summary-table

discussion.content: No inbound required. The article referenced in the answer that the ports listed are outbound only “ Endpoint data below lists requirements for connectivity from a user's machine to Office 365. It does not include network connections from Microsoft into a customer network, sometimes called hybrid or inbound network connections. See Additional endpoints for more information.”
